content:
=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Below is an analysis of the game based on the provided rules:

1. Game Genre and Style:
 • It’s essentially a puzzle-action platformer that combines exploration with resource collection, hazards, and enemies. Think along the lines of classic arcade adventure games (a bit like Spelunky) where you navigate a maze-like level, avoid dangers, and collect items.
 
2. Core Mechanics:
 • The game uses tiled sprites for environment (walls, dirt, background) and dynamic objects (boulders, diamonds, sword, enemies). Some sprites like walls and dirt are immovable, while others like boulders are “missiles” that move (fall slowly in this case).
 • The avatar is a “ShootAvatar” armed with a sword, meaning you can likely attack obstacles or enemies by projecting a weapon.
 • Resources (diamonds) are scattered for collection. Each collected diamond upgrades your score.
 • Physics‐like interactions occur: for example, boulders “step back” when they hit walls or dirt, and the avatar can defeat boulders by coming at them “from above” (albeit at a penalty in score). Other interactions include enemies (crabs, butterflies) affecting one another and even transforming one type into another (a butterfly hitting a crab becomes a diamond and gives bonus score).
 
3. Objective and Win/Loss Conditions:
 • The obvious goal is to successfully navigate the level and “exit” the stage. The exit is represented by an exit door.
 • However, an important twist is that the exit door reacts based on the resources (diamonds) you have. There is an interaction rule: when the avatar touches the exit door, if its diamond count exceeds a limit (here, 9) the door “kills” (or prevents) the avatar from exiting. This implies that resource management is key—you may need to be careful not to overload on diamonds.
 • The game ends in a loss when your avatar is killed (from enemy contact, falling boulders unless killed properly from above, or by mismanaging resources) and ends in a win when the exit door disappears (which in this game’s logic signals level completion).
 
4. Strategy Suggestions:
 • Navigation & Caution: Since the level is like a labyrinth with walls, dirt, and obstacles, carefully map out your route. Avoid or neutralize hazards like falling boulders by learning patterns of their movement. Always approach boulders from above to “kill” them safely, minding the score penalty.
 • Resource Management: Diamonds are good for scoring (+2 per diamond) but collecting too many can be dangerous when you try to exit. Aim to collect just up to the optimum number (around 9) to avoid triggering the exit door’s lethal reaction. Some interactions even give extra diamonds (like the butterfly–crab collision transforming into a diamond), so plan ahead.
 • Combat & Enemy Handling: Use your sword wisely—the fact that there is a limit of 1 and its “flickering” nature implies it might be a temporary or strategic asset rather than a constant power. Decide when to use it against enemies or obstacles (like clearing dirt, which in one rule is used to “kill” the sprite interacting with your sword).
 • Timing & Environmental Hazards: The behavior of boulders and even enemy movement (with “RandomNPC” for the enemy sprite) requires that you take your time. Learn enemy patterns, avoid unnecessary confrontations, and use the environment (like walls and dirt) to block hazards.
 
In summary:
You’re playing a platform-puzzle adventure where movement, careful combat, and resource regulation are all intertwined. The primary goal is to navigate the level safely, collect a beneficial—but capped—amount of diamonds, and then reach and use the exit door correctly to finish the level. The key strategy is balance: be cautious of falling hazards, use your sword and enemies interaction to your advantage, and manage your diamond collection so that you’re neither underpowered nor overburdened when trying to exit.

Happy gaming!

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game. 

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background dirt -> '.'
background -> '-'
background exitdoor -> 'e'
background boulder -> 'o'
background diamond -> 'x'
background crab -> 'c'
background butterfly -> 'b'
boulder -> '@'
butterfly -> '#'
crab -> '$'
diamond -> '%'
dirt -> '&'
exitdoor -> '*'
wall -> 'b'

Action:4  
I'm moving downwards from my current position (row 9, col 6) toward the exit door at row 10, col 6, expecting to progress safely if my diamond count is optimized as per the strategy.
